Play details
The English traveller. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1633. Date first performed: 1627?

Master Dalavill Young Geraldine Clowne Wincott Wife/Mistress Wincott Prudentella Old Geraldine Reiginald Robin Young Lionel Previous Owner Scapha Blanda Rioter Servant Tavern drawer Bess Master Ricott Wench Old Lionel Usurer Gentleman Gallant 1 Omnes Usurer's man Gallant 2 UNK

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter young Geraldine and master Dalauill.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
O friend, that I to mine own Notion
Had joined but your experience; I have the
Theoric, But you the Practic.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I perhaps, have seen what you
have only read of.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
There is your happiness.
A Scholar in his study knows the stars,
Their motion and their influence, which are fixed,
And which are wandering, can decipher Seas,
And give each several Land his proper bounds;
But set him to the Compass, he is to seek,
When a plain Pilot can, direct his course
From hence unto both the Indies; can bring back
His ship and charge, with profits quintuple.
I have read Jerusalem, and studied Rome,
Can tell in what degree each City stands,
Describe the distance of this place from that,
All this the Scale in every Map can teach,
Nay, for a need could punctually recite
The Monuments in either; but what I
Have by relation only, knowledge by travel
Which still makes up a complete Gentleman,
Proves eminent in you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I must confess,
I have seen Jerusalem and Rome, have brought
Mark from the one, from the other Testimony,
Know Spain, and France, and from their airs have sucked
A breath of every language: but no more
Of this discourse since we draw near the place
Of them we go to visit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Noble master Geraldine, worshipful master Dalauill.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I see thou still rememberest us.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Remember you, I have had so many memorandums from
the multiplicities of your bounties, that not to remember you were to
forget myself, you are both most ingeniously and nobly welcome.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: And why ingeniously and nobly?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Because had I given your welcomes other attributes than I
have done, the one being a Soldier, and the other seeming a Scholar,
I should have lied in the first, and showed myself a kind of blockhead
in the last.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I see your wit is nimble as your tongue,
But how doth all at home?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Small doings at home sir, in regard that the age of my Master
corresponds not with the youth of my Mistress, and you know cold
January and lusty May seldom meet in conjunction.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
I do not think but this fellow in time may for his wit and
understanding make Almanacs?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Not so sir, you being more judicious than I, I will give you the
preeminence in that, because I see by proof you have such judgment
in times and seasons.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: And why in times and seasons?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Because you have so seasonably made choice, to come so just at
dinner time; you are welcome Gentlemen, I will go tell my Master of
your coming.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: A pleasant knave.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
This fellow I perceive
Is well acquainted with his Masters mind,
O it is a good old man.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
And she a Lady
For Beauty and for Virtue unparalleled,
Nor can you name that thing to grace a woman
She has not in a full perfection,
Though in their years might seem disparity
And therefore at the first, a match unfit;
Imagine but his age and government,
Withal, her modesty, and chaste respect;
Betwixt them, there is so sweet a sympathy,
As crowns a noble marriage.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
It is acknowledged,
But to the worthy gentleman himself,
I am so bound in many courtesies,
That not the least, by all the expression
My Labour, or my Industry can show,
I will know how to cancel.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: O you are modest.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
He studies to engross me to himself,
And is so wedded to my company,
He makes me stranger to my Fathers house,
Although so near a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
This approves you,
To be most nobly propertied, that from one
So exquisite in Judgment, can Attract
So affectionate an eye.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Your Character,
I must bestow on his unmerited love,
As one that know I have it, and yet ignorant
Which way I should deserve it: Here both come.

div2.stage: Enter old Mr. Wincott, Wife, Prudentilla the sister, and the Clowne.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, welcome, but what need I use
A word so common, unto such to whom
My house was never private; I expect
You should not look for such a needles phrase,
Especially you Master Geraldine,
Your Father is my neighbour, and I know you,
Even from the Cradle, then I loved your Infancy,
And since your riper growth bettered by travel;
My wife and you, in youth were playfellows,
And nor now be strangers; as I take it,
Not above two years different in your Age.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So much he hath out stripped me.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
I would have you
Think this your home, free as your Fathers house,
And to command it, as the Master on it;
Call boldly here, and entertain your friends,
As in your own possessions, when I see it,
I will say you love me truly, not till then;
O what a happiness your Father hath,
Far above me, one to inherit after him,
Where I (Heaven knows) am childless.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
That defect
Heaven hath supplied in this your virtuous Wife,
Both fair, and full of all accomplishments,
My Father is a Widower, and herein
Your happiness transcends him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
O Master Geraldine,
Flattery in Men is an adjunct of their sex,
This Country breeds it, and for that, so far
You needed not to have travelled.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Truth is a word,
That should in every language relish well,
Nor have I that exceeded.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sir, my Husband
Hath took much pleasure in your strange discourse
About Jerusalem and the Holy Land;
How the new City differs from the old,
What ruins of the Temple yet remain,
And whether Sion, and those hills about,
With these Adjacent Towns and Villages,
Keep that proportioned distance as we read:
And then in Rome, of that great Pyramid
Reared in the Front, on four Lions Mounted,
How many of those Idol Temples stand,
First dedicated to their Heathen gods,
Which ruined, which to better use repaired,
Of their Panthæon, and their Capital,
What Structures are demolished, what remain.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
And what more pleasure to an old man's ear,
That never drew, save his own Countries air,
Than hear such things related. I do exceed him
In years, I must confess, Yet he much older
Than I in his experience.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
Master Geraldine,
May I be bold to ask you but one question,
The which I would be resolved in.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Anything, that lies within my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Put him to it,
Do Sister, you shall find him (make no doubt)
Most pregnant in his answer.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
In your travels
Through France, through Savoy, and through Italy,
Spain, and the Empire, Greece and Palestine,
Which breeds the choicest beauties.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
In troth Lady,
I never cast on any in those parts
A curious eye of censure, since my Travel
Was only aimed at Language, and to know;
These past me but as common objects did,
Seen, but not much regarded.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
O you strive
To express a most unheard of modesty,
And seldom found in any Traveller,
Especially of our Country, thereby seeking
To make yourself peculiar.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I should be loath
Profess in outward show to be one Man,
And prove myself another.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
One thing more,
Were you to marry, You that know these climes,
Their states and their conditions, out of which
Of all these countries would you choose your wife.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I will answer you in brief, (as I observe)
Each several clime for object, fare, or use,
Affords within itself, for all of these
What is most pleasing to the man there born;
Spain, that yields scant of food, affords the Nation
A parsimonious stomach, where our appetites
Are not content but with the large excess
Of a full table; where the pleasingest fruits
Are found most frequent, there they best content;
Where plenty flows, it asks abundant Feasts;
For so hath provident Nature dealt with all;
So in the choice of Women, the Greek wantons
Compelled beneath the Turkish slavery,
Vassal themselves to all men, and such best
Please the voluptuous, that delight in change;
The French is of one humour, Spain another,
The hot Italian he is a strain from both,
All pleased with their own nations even the Moore,
He thinks the blackest the most beautiful;
And Lady, since you so far tax my choice,
I will thus resolve you; Being an English man,
Amongst all these Nations I have seen or tried,
To please me best, here would I choose my bride.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p:
And happy were that Lady, in my thoughts,
Whom you would deign that grace to.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
How now Sister,
This is a fashion that is but late come up,
For maids to court their husbands.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
I would wife
It were no worse, upon condition,
They had my helping hand and purse to boot,
With both in ample measure; O this Gentleman,
I love, nay almost dote on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
You have my leave,
To give it full expression.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
In these arms then,
O had my youth been blessed with such a son,
To have made my estate to my name hereditary,
I should have gone contented to my grave,
As to my bed; to death, as to my sleep;
But Heaven hath will in all things, once more welcome,
And you sir, for your friends sake.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Would I had in me,
That which he hath, to have claimed, it for mine own,
How ever, I much thank you.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Now sir, the news with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Dancing news sir,
For the meat stands piping hot upon the dresser,
The kitchen is in a heat, and the Cook hath so bestirred himself,
That he is in a sweat. The Jack plays Music, and the Spits
Turn round to it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
This fellows my best clock,
He still strikes true to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And to supper too sir, I know not how the day goes with you,
but my stomach hath struck twelve, I can assure you that.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
You take us unprovided Gentlemen,
Yet something you shall find and we would rather
Give you the entertain of household guests,
Than complement of strangers, I pray enter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will stand to it, that in good hospitality, there can be nothing
found that is ill, he that is a good house-keeper, keeps a good table,
a good table, is never without good stools, good stools, seldom
without good guests, good guests, never without good cheer, good
cheer, cannot be without good stomachs, good stomachs, without
good digestion, good digestion, keeps men in good health, and therefore
all good people, that bear good minds, as you love goodness, be
sure to keep good meat and drink in your houses, and so you shall
be called good men, and nothing can come on it but good, I warrant
you.

div2.stage: Enter two seruing-men Reignald and Robin.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Away you Corridon.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Shall I be beat out of my Masters house thus?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Thy Master, we are Lords amongst ourselves,
And here we Live and Reign, Two years already
Are past of our great Empire, and we now
Write, Anno Tertio.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
But the old man lives,
That shortly will depose you.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
In the mean time,
I, as the mighty Lord and Seneschal
Of this great house and castle, banish thee,
The very smell at the kitchen, be it death,
To appear before the dresser,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And why so?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Because thou stinkest of garlic, is that breath
Agreeing with our Palace, where each Room,
Smells with Musk, Civet, and rich Amber-greece,
Aloes, Cassia, Aromatic gums,
Perfumes, and Pothers, one whose very garments
Scent of the folds and stables, O fie, fie,
What a base nasty rogue it is.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yet your fellow.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Then let us put a Cart-Horse in rich trappings.
And bring him to the Tilt-yard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Prank it, do,
Waste, Riot, and Consume, Misspend your Hours
In drunken Surfeits, lose your days in sleep,
And burn the nights in Revels, Drink and Drab,
Keep Christmas all year long, and blot lean Lent
Out of the Calendar; all that mass of wealth
Got by my Masters sweat and thrifty care,
Havoc in prodigal uses; Make all fly,
Pour it down your oily throats, or send it smoking
Out at the tops of chimneys: At his departure,
Was it the old man's charge to have his windows
Glister all night with Stars? his modest House
Turned to a common Stews? his Beds to pallets
Of Lusts and Prostitutions? his Buttery hatch
Now made more common than a Tavern's bar,
His Stools that welcomed none but civil guests,
Now only free for Panders, Whores and Bawds,
Strumpets, and such.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I suffer thee too long,
What is to me thy country, or to thee
The pleasure of our City? thou hast Cows,
Cattle, and Beeves to feed, Oves and Boves,
These that I keep, and in this pasture graze,
Are dainty Demoiselles, bonny Girls;
If thou beest born to Hedge, Ditch, Thrash and Plough
And I to Revel, Banquet and Carouse;
Thou Peasant, to the Spade and Pickaxe, I
The Baton and Stiletto think it only
Thy ill, my good, our several lots are cast,
And both must be contented.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: But when both our services are questioned.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Look thou to one,
My answer is provided.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Farewell Musk-Cat.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Adieu good Chief and Onions, stuff thy guts
With Speck and Barley-pudding for digestion,
Drink Whig and sour Milk, whilst I rinse my Throat,
With Bordeaux and Canary.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: What was he?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
A Spy Sir,
One of their Hinds of the country, that came prying
To see what dainty fare our kitchen yields,
What Guests we harbour, and what rule we keep,
And threats to tell the old man when he comes;
I think I sent him packing.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: It was well done.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
A whoreson Jack-an-apes, a base Baboon,
To insinuate in our secrets.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Let such keep, the Country where their charge is.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: So I said Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
And visit us when we command them thence,
Not search into our counsels.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: It were not fit.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Who in my fathers absence should command,
Save I his only son?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: It is but justice.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: For am not I now Lord?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Dominus fac totum.
And am not I your Steward?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Well remembered,
This night I have a purpose to be Merry,
Jovial and Frolic, how doth our cash hold out?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: The bag is still heavy.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Then my heart is still light.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I can assure you, yet it is pretty deep,
though scarce a mile to bottom.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Let me have
to Supper, Let me see, a Duck -

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Sweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: A Capon -

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Geld the Rascal.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Then a Turkey -

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Now spit him for an Infidel.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Green Plover, Snite,
Partridge, Lark, Cock, and Pheasant.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Never a Wigeon?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Yes, wait thyself at Table.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Where I hope yourself will not be absent.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Nor my friends.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: We will have them then in plenty.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Caviar, Sturgeon, Anchovies, pickle Oysters: Yes,
And a Potato Pie; besides all these,
What thou thinkst rare and costly.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Sir, I know
What is to be done; the stock that must be spent,
Is in my hands, and what I have to do,
I will do suddenly.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
No Butchers meat,
Of that, beware in any case.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I still remember,
Your father was no Grazier, if he were,
This were a way to eat up all his Fields,
Hedges and all.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: You will be gone sir.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Yes, and you are in the way going.

div2.stage: Enter Blanda a Whore, and Scapha a Bawde.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
To what may young men best compare themselves?
Better to what, than to a house new built?
The Fabric strong, the Chambers well contrived,
Polished within, without, well beautified;
When all that gaze upon the Edifice,
Do not alone commend the workman's craft,
But either make it their fair president
By which to build another, or at least,
Wish there to inhabit: Being set to sale,
In comes a slothful Tenant, with a Family
As lazy and debauched; Rough tempests rise,
Until the roof, which by their idleness,
Left unrepaired, the stormy showers beat in,
Rot the main Posts and Rafters, spoil the Rooms,
Deface the Ceilings, and in little space,
Bring it to utter Ruin, yet the fault,
Not in the Architector that first reared it,
But him that should repair it: So it fares
With us young men; WeHtp; are those houses made,
Our Parents raise these Structures, the foundation
Laid in our Infancy; and as we grow
In years, they strive to build us by degrees,
Story on story higher; up at height,
They cover us with Counsel, to defend us
From storms without: they polish us within,
With Learnings, Knowledge, Arts and Disciplines;
All that is naught and vicious, they sweep from us,
Like Dust and Cobwebs, and our Rooms concealed,
Hang with the costliest hangings; Bout the Walls,
Emblems and beauteous Symbols pictured round;
But when that lazy Tenant, Love, steps in,
And in his Train, brings Sloth and Negligence,
Lust, Disobedience, and profuse Excess;
The Thrift with which our fathers tiled our Roofs,
Submits to every storm and Winters blast,
And yielding place to every riotous sin,
Gives way without, to ruin what is within:
Such is the state I stand in.

sp.speaker: Blan.
sp.p: And how doth this Tire become me?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p:
Rather ask, how your sweet carriage,
And Court behaviour, doth best grace you, for Lover's regard,
Not so much the outward habit, as that which the garment covers.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
O here is that Hail, Shower, Tempest, Storm, and Gust,
That shattered hath this building; Let in Lust,
Intemperance appetite to Vice; withal,
Neglect of every Goodness; Thus I see,
How I am sinking in mine own disease,
Yet can I not abide it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
And how this Gown? I prithee view me well,
And speak with thy best Judgment.

sp.speaker: Sca.
Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Let me not live, but she speaks naught but truth,
And I will for that reward her.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
All is one to me, become they me, or not,
Or be I fair, or foul, in others eyes,
So I appear so to my Lionell,
He is the glass, in whom I judge my face,
By whom in order, I will dress these curls,
And place these Jewels, only to please him,
Why dost smile.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p:
To hear a Woman, that thinks herself so wise, speak so
foolishly, that knows well, and does ill.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Teach me wherein I err.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p:
I will tell thee Daughter; In that thou knowest thyself to be
beloved of so many, and settlest thy affection, only upon one; Doth the
Mill grind only, when the Wind sits in one corner? Or Ships only
Sail, when it is in this, or that quarter? Is he a cunning Fencer, that
lies but at one Guard? Or he a Skilful Musician, that plays but on
one String? Is there but one way to the Wood? And but one Bucket
that belongs to the Well? To affect one, and despise all other, becomes
the precise Matron, not the Prostitute; the loyal Wife, not the loose
Wanton: Such have I been, as you are now, and should learn, to
Sail with all Winds, defend all Blows, make Music with all
Strings, know all the ways, to the Wood, and like a good travelling
Hackney, learn to drink of all Waters.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
Bla.
sp.p:
I would not have you Mother, teach me aught,
That tends to injure him.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p:
Well look to it when it is too late, and then repent at leisure,
as I have done; Thou seest, here is nothing but Prodigality and Pride,
Wantoning, and Wasting, Rioting, and Revelling, Spoiling, and
Spending, Gluttony, and Gourmandizing, all goes to Havoc, and
can this hold out? When he hath nothing left, to help himself, how
can he Harbour thee? Look at length, to Drink from a dry Bottle,
and feed from an empty Knapsack, look to it, it will come to that.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
My parsimony shall begin in thee,
And instantly, for from this hour, I vow,
That thou no more shalt Drink upon my cost,
Nor taste the smallest Fragment from my Board;
I will see thee starve in the street first.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p:
Live to one man? a jest, thou mayst as well, tie thyself to one
Gown; and what Fool, but will change with the Fashion, Yes, do,
Confine thyself to one Garment, and use no Variety, and see how
soon it will Rot, and turn to Rags.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Those Rags, be thy Reward; O my sweet Blanda,
Only for Thee, I wish my Father dead,
And never to Rouse us from our Sweet delight;
But for this Hag, this Beldam, she whose back,
Hath made her Items, in my Mercers Books,
Whose ravenous Guts, I have Stuffed with Delicates,
Nay even to Surfeit; And whose frozen Blood,
I have Warmed with Aquauitæ; Be this day
My last of Bounty, to a Wretch Ingrate,
But unto Thee, a new Indenture Sealed,
Of an affection fixed, and Permanent,
I will love thee still, be it but to give the lie,
To this old Cankered Worm.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Nay, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
With thee, my Soul shall ever be at peace,
But with this love seducer, still at War.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Here me but speak.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Ope but thy lips again, it makes a way,
To have thy Tongue plucked out.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: What all in Tempest?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Yes, and the Storm, raised by that Witches Spells.
O it is a Damned Enchantress.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: What is the business?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
Only some few words, slipped her unawares,
For my Sake, make her peace.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p:
You charge me deeply,
Come Friend, will you be Moved at women's Words,
A man of your known judgment?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Had you but heard,
The damned Erroneous Doctrine that she taught,
You would have judged her to the Stake.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
But Sweet heart,
She now Recants those Errors, once more Number her
Amongst your Household servants.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: Shall she beg, and be denied aught from you?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Come this Kiss, Shall end all former quarrels.

sp.speaker: Rio.
Y. Lio.
sp.p:
You have prevailed,
But upon this Condition, no way else,
I will Censure her, as she hath Sentenced thee;
But with some small Inversion,

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: Speak, how is that?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
Not too severe, I prithee, see poor wretch,
She at the bar, stands quaking.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Now, hold up?

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: How man, how?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Her hand, I mean; And now I will sentence thee,
According to thy Counsel given to her:
Sail by one Wind; Thou shalt, to one tune Sing,
Lie at one Guard, and Play but on one String,
Henceforth, I will Confine thee to one Garment,
And that shall be a cast one, Like thyself
Just, past all Wearing, as thou past all Use,
And not to be renewed, till it be as Ragged,
As thou art Rotten.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Nay sweet.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: That for her Habit.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: A cold Suit, I have on it.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
To prevent Surfeit,
Thy Diet, shall be to one Dish confined,
And that too Rifled, with as unclean hands,
As ever were laid on thee.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: What he scants me in Victuals, would he but allow me in Drink.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
That shall be the refuse of the Flagons, Jacks,
And Snuffs, such as the nastiest Breathes shall leave;
Of Wine, and Strong-water, never hope,
Henceforth to Smell.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: O me, I Faint already.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
If I sink in my State, of all the rest,
Be thou excused, what thou proposed to her,
Beldam, is now against thyself decreed,
Drink from dry springs, from empty Knapsacks feed.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: No burnt Wine, nor Hot-waters.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Take her hence.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Indeed you are too cruel.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
Rio.
sp.p:
Fear not Sir,
You will have a full Table.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: What, and Music?

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: Best Consort in the City, for six parts.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: We shall have Songs then?

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: By the ear.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: And Wenches?

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: Yes by the eye.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Ha, what was that you said?

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p:
We shall have such to bear you company,
As will no doubt content you.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Enter then:
In Youth there is a Fate, that sways us still,
To know what is Good, and yet pursue what is Ill.

div2.stage: Enter old Master Wincott, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: And what is this Dalauill?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
My apprehension,
Can give him no more true expression,
Than that he first appears, a Gentleman,
And well conditioned.

sp.speaker: Winc.
Wife.
sp.p:
I have not Eyes,
To search into the inward Thoughts of Men,
Nor ever was studied in that Art,
To judge of Men's affection by the face;
But that which makes me best opinioned of him,
Is, That he is Companion, and the Friend
Beloved of him, whom you so much commend,
The Noble Master Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Thou hast spoke,
That which not only crowns his true desert,
But now instates him, in my better thoughts,
Making his Worth, unquestioned.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
He pretends
Love to my sister Prudentella I have observed him,
Single her out, to private conference.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
But I could rather, for her own sake, wish
Young Geraldine would fix his thoughts that way,
And she towards him; In such Affinity,
Trust me, I would not use a sparing hand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
But Love in these kinds, should not be compelled,
Forced, nor Persuaded; When it freely Springs,
And of itself, takes voluntary Root,
It Grows, it Spreads, it Ripens, and brings forth,
Such an Usurious Crop of timely Fruit,
As crowns a plenteous Autumn.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Such a Harvest,
I should not be the ungladdest man to see,
Of all thy sisters friends: Now, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Who, I Sir, From a Lodging of Largess, a House of Hospitality,
and a Palace of Plenty; Where there is Feeding like Horses, and
Drinking like Fishes; Where for Pints, we are served in Pottles; and in
stead of Pottle-pots, in Pails; in stead of Silver tankards, we drink
out of Water-tankards; Claret runs as freely, as the Cocks; and
Canary, like the Conduits of a Coronation day; Where there is nothing
but Feeding and Frolicking; Carving in Kissing; Drinking, and
Dancing; Music and Madding; Fiddling and Feasting.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: And where, I pray thee, are all these Revels kept?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
They may be rather called Reeks than Revels; As I came along
by the door, I was called up amongst them; He-Gallants, and
She-Gallants, I no sooner looked out, but saw them out with their
Knives, Slashing of Shoulders, Mangling of Legs, and Launching of
Loins, till there was scarce a whole Limb left amongst them.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: A fearful Massacre.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
One was Hacking to cut off a Neck, this was Mangling a Breast,
his Knife slip from the Shoulder, and only cut of a Wing, one was
picking the Brains out of a Head, another was Knuckle deep in a
Belly, one was Groping for a Liver, another Searching for the Kidneys;
I saw one pluck the Sole from the Body (Goose that she was
to suffer it) another pricked into the Breast with his one Bill, Woodcock
to endure it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How fell they out at first?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I know not that, but it seems, one had a Stomach, and another
had a Stomach; But there was such biting and tearing with
their teeths, that I am sure, I saw some of their poor Carcasses
pay for it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Did they not send for Surgeons?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Alas no, Surgeons help was too late; There was no stitching
up of those Wounds, where Limb was plucked from Limb; Nor any
Salve for those Scars, which all the Plaster of Paris cannot Cure.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Where grew the quarrel first?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It seems it was first Broached in the Kitchen; Certain creatures
being brought in thither, by some of the House; The Cook being
a Choleric fellow, did so Towse them and Toss them, so Pluck
them and Pull them, till he left them as naked as my Nail, Pinioned
some of them like Felons; Cut the Spurs from others of their
Heels; Then down went his Spits, Some of them he ran in at the
Throat, and out at the Back-side; About went his basting-laddie,
where he did so besauce them, that many a shrewd turn they had
amongst them.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But in all this, How did the Women scape?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
They fared best, and did the least hurt that I saw; But for
quietness sake, were forced to swallow what is not yet digested, yet
everyone had their share, and she that had least, I am sure by this
time, hath her belly full.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: And where was all this havoc kept?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, at your next neighbours, Young Master Lionell,
Where there is nothing but Drinking out of Dry-Fats, and Healthing
in Half-Tubs, his Guests are fed by the Belly, and Beggars served at
his Gate in Baskets; He is the Adamant of this Age, the Daffodil
of these days, the Prince of Prodigality, and the very Cæsar of all
young Citizens.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Belike then, it was a Massacre of meat, not as I apprehended?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Your gravity hath guessed aright; The chiefest that fell in this
Battle, were wild Foul and tame Foul; Pheasants were wounded in
stead of Alfares, and Capons for Captains, Anchovies stood for Ancients,
and Caviar for Corporals, Dishes were assaulted in stead of
Ditches, and Rabbits were cut to pieces upon the rebellings, some lost
their Legs, whilst other of their wings were forced to fly; The Pioner
undermined nothing but Pie-crust; And -

sp.speaker: Wine.
sp.p:
Enough, enough, your wit hath played too long upon our patience;
Wife, it grieves me much both for the young and old man, the one,
Graces his head with care, endures the parching heat and biting cold,
The terrors of the Lands, and fears at Sea in travel, only to gain
Some competent estate to leave his son;
Whiles all that Merchandise, through Gulfs, Cross-Tides,
Pirates and Storms, he brings so far; The other
Here Shipwrecks in the Harbour.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It is the care of Fathers; and the weakness
Incident to youth, that wants experience.

div2.stage: Enter Y. Geraldine, Dallauill, Prudentilla, laughing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I was at the beginning of the Battle,
But here comes some, that it seems
Were at the rifling of the dead Carcasses;
For by their mirth, they have had part of the Spoil.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
You are pleasant, Gentlemen, what I entreat,
Might be the Subject of your pleasant sport,
It promiseth some pleasure?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
If their recreation
Be, as I make no question, on truth grounded,
it will beget sudden laughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What is the Project?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Who shall relate it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Master Geraldine, if there be anything can please my Ear,
With pleasant sounds, your Tongue must be the Instrument,
On which the String must strike.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Be it his then.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: Nay hear it, it is a good one.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: We entreat you, Possess us of the Novel,

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Speak, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I shall then, with a kind of Barbarism,
Shadow a Jest, that asks a smoother Tongue,
For in my poor discourse, I do protest,
it will but lose his lustre.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are Modest.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: However speak, I pray; For my sake do it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
This is like a hasty Pudding, longer in eating, than it was
in making.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Then thus it was, this Gentleman and I,
Past but just now, by your next Neighbours house,
Where as they say, dwells one Young Lionell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Where I was tonight at Supper.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: An unthrift Youth, his Father now at Sea.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Why that is the very Subject, upon which
It seems, this Jest is grounded, there this Night,
Was a great feast.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why so I told you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Be thou still dumb, it is he that I would hear.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
In the height of their Carousing, all their brains,
Warmed with the heat of Wine; Discourse was offered,
Of Ships, and Storms at Sea; when suddenly,
Out of his giddy wildness, one conceives
The Room wherein they quaffed, to be a Pinnace,
Moving and Floating; and the confused Noise,
To be the murmuring Winds, Gusts, Mariners;
That their unsteadfast Footing, did proceed
From rocking of the Vessel: This conceived,
Each one begins to apprehend the danger,
And to look out for safety, fly saith one
Up to the Main-top, and discover; He
Climbs by the bed post, to the Tester, there
Reports a Turbulent Sea and Tempest towards;
And wills them if they will save their Ship and lives,
To cast their Lading overboard; At this
All fall to Work, and Hoist into the Street,
As to the Sea, What next come to their hand,
Stools, Tables, Trestles, Trenchers, Bed-steads, Cups,
Pots, Plate, and Glasses; Here a fellow Whistles,
They take him for the Boatswain, one lies struggling
Upon the floor, as if he swam for life,
A third, takes the Base-viol for the the Cock-boat,
Sits in the belly on it, labours and Rows;
His Oar, the Stick with which the Fiddler played;
A fourth, bestrides his Fellows, thinking to scape
As did Arion, on the Dolphins back,
Still fumbling on a gittern.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Excellent Sport.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: But what was the conclusion?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
The rude multitude,
Watching without, and gaping for the spoil
Cast from the windows, went by the ears about it;
The Constable is called to Atone the broil,
Which done, and hearing such a noise within,
Of eminent Shipwreck; enters the house, and finds them
In this confusion, They Adore his staff,
And think it Neptune's Trident, and that he
Comes with his Tritons, (so they called his watch)
To calm the Tempest, and appease the Waves;
And at this point, we left them.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Come what will, I will steal out of Doors,
And see the end of it, that is certain.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Thanks Master Geraldine, for this discourse,
In troth it hath much pleased me, but the night
Begins to grow fast on us, for your parts,
You are all young, and you may sit up late,
My eyes begin to summon me to sleep,
And nothing is more offensive unto Age,
Than to watch long and late.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Now good Rest with you.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
What says fair Prudentilla? Maids and Widows,
And we young Bachelors, such as indeed
Are forced to lie in Solitary beds,
And sleep without disturbance; we methinks,
Should desire later hours; when Married Wines,
That in their amorous arms, hug their delights;
To often waking subject; their more haste,
May better be excused.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
How can you,
That are as you confess, a single man,
Enter so far into these Mystical secrets
Of Marriage, which as yet you never proved.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
There There is Lady, an instinct innate in man,
Which prompts us to the apprehensions
Of the uses we were born to; Such we are
Aptest to learn; Ambitious most to know,
Of which our chief is Marriage.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
What you Men
Most meditate, we Women seldom dream of.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: When dream Maids most?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: When think you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: When you lie upon your Backs, come come, your Ear.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: We now are left alone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Why say we be who should be jealous of us?
This is not first of many hundred Nights,
That we two have been private, from the first
Of our acquaintance, when our Tongues but clipped
Our Mothers-tongue, and could not speak it plain,
We knew each other; As in stature, so
Increased our sweet Society, Since your travel,
And my late Marriage, Through my Husbands love,
Mid-night hath been as Mid-day, and my Bed-chamber,
As free to you, as your own Fathers house,
And you as welcome to it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I must confess,
It is in you, your Noble Courtesy,
In him, a more than common confidence,
And in this Age, can scarce find president.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Most true, it is withal an Argument,
That both our virtues are so deep impressed
In his good thoughts, he knows we cannot err.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
A villain were he, to deceive such trust,
Or (were there one) a much worse Character.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
And she no less, whom either Beauty, Youth,
Time, Place, or opportunity could tempt,
To injure such a Husband.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Wife.
sp.p:
I know your meaning,
It was once voiced, that we two should have Matched,
The World so thought, and many Tongues so spake,
But Heaven hath now disposed us otherways;
And being as it is, (a thing in me,
Which I protest, was never wished, nor sought)
Now done, I not repent it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
In those times,
Of all the Treasures of my Hopes and Love,
You were the Exchequer, they were Stored in you;
And had not my unfortunate Travel crossed them,
They had been here reserved still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Troth they had,
I should have been your trusty Treasurer.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Wife.
sp.p:
If they should not,
We might proclaim, they were not Charitable,
Which were a deadly sin but to conceive.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Will you resolve me one thing?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
As to one, that in my Bosom hath a second place,
next my dear Husband.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
That is the thing I crave,
And only that, to have a place next him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Presume on that already, but perhaps,
You mean to stretch it further.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Only thus far,
Your Husbands old, to whom my Soul doth wish,
A Nestor's age, So much he merits from me;
Yet if (as proof and Nature daily teach)
Men cannot always live, especially
Such as are old and Crazed; He be called hence,
Fairly, in full maturity of time,
And we two be reserved to after life,
Will you confer your Widow-hood on me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
You ask the thing, I was about to beg;
Your tongue hath spake mine own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Vow to that.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: As I hope Mercy.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
It is enough, that word
Alone, instates me happy; Now so please you,
We will divide, you to your private Chamber,
I to find out my friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Nay Master Geraldine, one Ceremony rests yet unperformed,
My Vow is past, your oath must next proceed,
And as you covet to be sure of me,
Of you I would be certain.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Make ye doubt?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
No doubt; but Love is still Jealous, and in that
To be excused; You then shall swear by Heaven,
And as in all your future Acts, you hope
To thrive and prosper; As the Day may yield
Comfort, or the Night rest, as you would keep
Entire, the Honour of your Fathers house,
And free your Name from Scandal and Reproach,
By all the Goodness that you hope to enjoy,
Or ill to shun -

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: You charge me deeply Lady.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Till that day come, you shall reserve yourself
A single man; Converse nor company
With any Woman, Contract nor Combine,
With Maid, or Widow; which expected hour,
As I do wish not haste, so when it happens,
It shall not come unwelcome; You here all, Vow this.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
By all that you have said, I swear,
and by this Kiss Confirm.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
You are now my Brother,
But then, my second Husband.

div2.stage: Enter Y. Lionell, Rioter, Blanda, Scapha, two Gallants, and two Wenches, as newly wak'd from sleepe.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: We had a stormy night on it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
The Wine still works,
And with the little rest they have took tonight,
They are scarce come to themselves.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Now it is a Calm,
Thanks to those gentle Sea-gods, that have brought us
To this safe Harbour; Can you tell their names?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: He with the Painted-staff, I heard you call Neptune.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
The dreadful god of Seas,
Upon whose back never stuck March flees.

sp.speaker: 1. Gall.
sp.p:
One with the Bill, keeps Neptune's Porpoises,
So Ovid says in his Metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: 2. Gall.
sp.p:
A third the learned Poets write on,
And as they say, His name is Triton.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
These are the Marine gods, to whom my father
In his long voyage prays to; Cannot they
That brought us to our Haven, bury him
In their Abyss? For if he safe arrive,
I with these Sailors, Syrens, and what not,
Am sure here to be shipwrecked.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.p: Stand up stiff.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: But that the ship so totters: I shall fall.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.p: If thou fall, I will fall with thee.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p:
Now I sink,
And as I dive and drown, Thus by degrees,
I will pluck thee to the bottom.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Amain for England, See, see,
The Spaniard now strikes Sail.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: So must you all.

sp.speaker: 1. Gall.
sp.p: Whence is your ship, from the Bermoothes?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Worse, I think from Hell:
We are all Lost, Split, Shipwrecked, and undone,
This place is a mere quick-sands.

sp.speaker: 2. Gall.
sp.p: So we feared.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Where is my young Master?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Here man; speak, the News?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: The News is, I, and you -

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: She, and all these -

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
We, and all ours, are in one turbulent Sea
Of Fear, Despair, Disaster and mischance swallowed:
Your father, Sir -

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Why, what of him?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: He is, O I want breath.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Landed, and at hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Upon what coast? Who saw him?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: I, these eyes.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: O Heaven, what shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Bla.
sp.p: Ho, Rioter, awake.

sp.speaker: Rio.
Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Arise, I say,
My Fathers come from Sea.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: If he be come, Bid him be gone again.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Can you trifle at such a time, when your Inventions.
Brains, Wits, Plots, Devices, Stratagems, and all
Should be at one in action? each of you
That love your safeties, lend your helping hands,
Women and all, to take this drunkard hence,
And to bestow him else where.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Lift for Heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
But what am I the nearer, were all these
Conveyed to sundry places and unseen;
The stain of our disorders still remain,
Of which, the house will witness, and the old man
Must find when he enters; And for these
I am here left to answer: What is he gone?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
But whither? But into the self same house
That harbours him; my Fathers, where we all
Attend from him surprise all.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Y. Lio.
sp.p: To this house?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Your Fathers, with your Sweet-heart, these and all;
Nay, no more words but do it,

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: That were to betray us to his fury.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I have ithere,
To Bail you hence at pleasure; and in the interim,
I will make this supposed Goal, to you, as safe
From the injured old man's just incensed spleen,
As were you now together in the low countries,
Virginia, or in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
Present fear,
Bids us to yield unto the faint belief
Of the least hoped safety.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Will you in?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: By thee we will be counselled.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Shut them fast.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: And thou and I to leave them?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
No such thing, for you shall bear your Sweet-heart company,
And help to cheer the rest.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
And so thou
Meanest to escape alone?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Y. Lio.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
And though the old man thunder at the gates
As if he meant to ruin what he had reared,
None on their lives to answer.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
It is my charge;
Remains there nothing else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Only the Key; for I must play the jailer for your durance,
To be the Mercury in your release.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
Me and my hope, I in this Key deliver
To thy safe trust.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
When you are fast you are safe,
And with this turn it is done: What fools are these,
To trust their ruined fortunes to his hands
That hath betrayed his own; And make themselves
Prisoner to one deserves to lie for all,
As being cause of all; And yet something prompts me,
I will stand it at all dangers; And to recompense
The many wrongs unto the young man done:
Now, if I can doubly delude the old,
My brain, about it then; All is hushed within,
The noise that shall be, I must make without;
And he that part for gain, and part for wit,
So far hath travelled, strive to fool at home:
Which to effect, Art must with Knavery join,
And smooth Dissembling meet with Impudence;
I will do my best, and howsoever it prove,
My praise or shame, it is but a servant's love.

div2.stage: Enter old Lionell like a ciuill Merchant, with Water-man, and two seruants with Burdens and Caskets.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Discharge these honest Sailors that have brought
Our Chests a shore, and pray them have a care,
Those merchandise be safe we left aboard:
As Heaven hath blessed us with a fortunate Voyage,
In which we bring home riches with our healths,
So let not us prove niggards in our store,
See them paid well, and to their full content.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Then return: These special things,
And of most value, we will not trust aboard;
Methinks they are not safe till they see home,
And there repose, where we will rest ourselves,
And bid farewell to Travel; for I vow,
After this hour, no more to trust the Seas,
Nor throw me to such danger.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I could wish
You had took your leave of the Land too.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
And now it much rejoiceth me, to think
What a most sudden welcome I shall bring,
both to my Friends and private Family.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
O, but how much more welcome had he been,
That had brought certain tidings of thy death.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But soft, what is this? my own gates shut upon me,
And bar their Master entrance? Who is within there?
How, no man speak, are all asleep or dead,
That no soul stirs to open?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
What mad man is that, who weary of his life,
Dares once lay hand on these accursed gates?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Who is that? my servant Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
My old Master,
Most glad I am to see you; Are you well Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Thou seest I am.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
But are you sure you are?
Feel you no change about you? Pray you stand off.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
What strange and unexpected greetings this,
That thus a man may knock at his own gates,
Beat with his hands and feet, and call thus loud,
And no man give him entrance?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Said you Sir;
Did your hand touch that hammer?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why, whose else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: But are you sure you touch it?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: How else, I prithee, could I have made this noise?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: You touched it then?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I tell thee yet I did.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
O for the love I bear you,
O me most miserable, you, for you own sake,
Of all alive most wretched; Did you touch it?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why, say I did?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p:
It is past hope,
The deed is done, and I repent it not.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
You and all yours will do it. In this one rashness,
You have undone us all; Pray be not desperate,
But first thank Heaven that you have escaped thus well;
Come from the gate, yet further, further yet,
And tempt your fate no more; Command your servants
Give off and come no nearer, they are ignorant,
And do not know the danger, therefore pity
That they should perish in it; It is full seven months,
Since any of your house durst once set foot
Over that threshold.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Prithee speak the cause?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
First look about, beware that no man hear,
Command these to remove.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Be gone.
Now speak.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
O Sir, This horse is grown Prodigious,
Fatal, Disastrous unto you and yours.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p: What Fatal? what Disastrous?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Some Host that hath been owner of this house,
In it his Guest hath slain; And we suspect
It was he of whom you bought it.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
How came this
Discovered to you first?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I will tell you Sir,
But further from the gate: Your son one night
Supped late abroad, I within; O that night,
I never shall forget; Being safe got home,
I saw him in his chamber laid to rest;
And after went to mine, and being drowsy,
Forgot by chance, to put the Candle out;
Being dead asleep; Your son affrighted, calls
So loud, that I soon wakened; Brought in light,
And found him almost drowned in fearful sweat;
Amazed to see it, I did demand the cause:
Who told me, that this murdered Ghost appeared,
His body gashed, and all over-stuck with wounds;
And spake to him as follows.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: O proceed, it is that I long to hear.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I am, quoth he,
A Transmarine by birth, who came well stored
With Gold and Jewels, to this fatal house;
Where seeking safety, I encountered death:
The covetous Merchant, Land-lord of this rent,
To whom I gave my life and wealth in charge;
Freely to enjoy the one, robbed me of both:
Here was my body buried, here my Ghost
Must ever walk, till that have Christian right;
Till when, my habitation must be here:
Then fly young man, Remove thy family,
And seek some safer dwelling: For my death,
This mansion is accursed; It is my possession,
Bought at the dear rate of my life and blood,
None enter here, that aims at his own good.
And with this charge he vanished.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
O my fear,
Whither wilt thou transport me?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: I Entreat keep further from the gate, and fly.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Fly whither? Why dost not thou fly too?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: What need I fear, the Ghost and I am friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: But Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Tush, I nothing have deserved,
Nor aught transgressed: I came not near the gate.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: To whom was that thou spakest?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Was it you Sir named me?
Now as I live, I thought the dead man called,
To enquire for him that thundered at the gate
Which he so dearly paid for: Are you mad,
To stand a foreseen danger?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Cover you head and fly; Lest looking back,
You spy your own confusion.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why dost not thou fly too?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I tell you Sir,
The Ghost and I am friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why didst thou quake then?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
In fear lest some mischance may fall on you,
That have the dead offended, For my part,
The Ghost and I am friends: Why fly you not,
Since here you are not safe?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Some blessed powers guard me.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, I will not forsake you: I have got the start;
But ere the goal, it will ask both Brain and Art.

div2.stage: Enter old Master Geraldine, Y. Geraldine, MasterWincott , and Wife, Dalauill, Prudentilla.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
We are bound to you, kind Master Geraldine,
For this great entertainment; Troth your cost
Hath much exceeded common neighbour-hood:
You have feasted us like Princes.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
This, and more
Many degrees, can never countervail
The oft and frequent welcomes given my son:
You have took him from me quite, and have I think,
Adopted him into your family,
He stays with me so seldom.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
And in this,
By trusting him to me, of whom yourself
May have both use and pleasure, you are as kind
As moneyed men, that might make benefit
Of what they are possessed, yet to their friends
In need, will lend it gratis.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
And like such,
As are indebted more than they can pay;
We more and more confess ourselves engaged
To you, for your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
Yet you see,
Like Debtors, such as would not break their day;
The Treasure late received, we tender back,
The which, the longer you can spare, you still
The more shall bind us to you.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Most kind Ladies,
Worthy you are to borrow, that return
The Principal, with such large use of thanks.

sp.speaker: Dal.
Winc.
sp.p:
You have Master Geraldine,
Fair walks and gardens, I have praised them,
Both to my Wife and Sister.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
You would see them,
There is no pleasure that the House can yield,
That can be debarred from you; prithee Son,
Be thou the Usher to those Mounts and Prospects
May one day call thee Master.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Sir I shall; Please you to walk.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
What Master Dalauill,
Will you not bear us company.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
It is not fit
That we should leave our Noble host alone,
Be you my Friends charge, and this old man mine.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: Well, be it then at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
You to your Prospects, but there is project here
That is of another Nature; Worthy Sir,
I cannot but approve your happiness,
To be the Father of so brave a Son,
So every way accomplished and made up,
In which my voice is least; For I alas,
Bear but a mean part in the common choir,
When with much louder accents of his praise,
So all the world reports him.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Thank my Stars,
They have lent me one, who as he always was.
And is my present joy; If their aspect
Be no ways to our goods Malevolent,
May be my Future comfort.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Yet must I hold him happy above others,
As one that Solely to himself enjoys
What many others aim at; But in vain.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: How mean you that?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: So Beautiful a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: A Mistress, said you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, or a Friend,
Whether you please to style her.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Mistress? Friend?
Pray be more open languaged.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
And indeed,
Who can blame him to absent himself from home,
And make his Fathers house but as a grange,
For a Beauty so Attractive? Or blame her,
Hugging so weak an old Man in her arms,
To make a new choice, of an equal youth,
Being in him so Perfect? yet In troth,
I think they both are honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
You have Sir,
Possessed me with such strange fancies.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
For my part,
How can I love the person of your Son,
And not his reputation? His repair
So often to the House, is voiced by all,
And frequent in the mouths of the whole Country,
Some equally addicted, praise his happiness;
But others, more Censorious and Austere,
Blame and reprove a course so dissolute;
Each one in general, pity the good man,
As one unfriendly dealt with, yet in my conscience,
I think them truly Honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: It is suspicious.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
True Sir, at best; But what when scandalous tongues
Will make the worst? and what good in itself,
Sully and stain by fabulous mes-report;
For let men live as chary as they can,
Their lives are often questioned, Then no wonder,
If such as give occasion of suspicion,
Be subject to this scandal: What I speak,
Is as a Noble Friend unto your Son;
And therefore, as I glory in his Fame,
I suffer in his wrong; for as I live,
I think, they both are honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Howsoever, I wish them so.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Some course might be devised,
To stop this clamour ere it grow too rank;
Lest that which yet but inconvenience seems,
May turn to greater mischief; This I speak
In Zeal to both, in sovereign care of him
As of a Friend; And tender of her Honour,
As one to whom I hope to be allied,
By Marriage with her Sister.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
I much thank you,
For you have clearly given me light of that,
Till now I never dreamt on.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
It is my Love,
And therefore I entreat you, make not me
To be the first reporter.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
You have done
The office of a Noble Gentleman,
And shall not be so injured.

div2.stage: Enter againe as from Walking Winc. Wife, Y. Ger. Prud.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
See Master Geraldine,
How bold we are, especially these Ladies
Play little better than the thieves with you,
For they have robbed your Garden.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
You might Sir,
Better have termed it sauciness, than theft;
You see we blush not, what we took in private,
To wear in public view.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
Besides, these cannot
Be missed out of so many; in full fields,
The gleanings are allowed.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
These and the rest,
Are Ladies, at your service.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Now to horse,
But one thing ere we part, I must entreat;
In which my Wife will be joint suitor with me,
My Sister too.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: In what I pray.

sp.speaker: Winc.
Old. Ger.
sp.p:
How men are born,
To woe their own disasters?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
But to see us
From whence he brought us Sir, that is all.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
This second motion makes it Palpable:
To note a Woman's cunning; Make her husband
Bawd to her own lascivious appetite,
And to Solicit his own shame.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
Nay Sir,
When all of us join in so small a suit,
It were some injury to be denied.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
And work her Sister too; What will not woman
To accomplish her own ends: But this disease,
I will seek to Physic ere it grow too far:
I am most sorry to be urged sweet Friends,
In what at this time I can no ways grant;
Most, that these Ladies should be aught denied,
To whom I owe all Service, but occasions
Of weighty and important consequence,
Such as concern the best of my Estate,
Call him aside; excuse us both this once,
Presume this business is no sooner over,
But he is at his own freedom.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
It were no manners
In us to urge it further, we will leave you,
With promise Sir, that he shall in my will,
Not be the last remembered.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
Y. Ger.
sp.p: Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Remember your last promise.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Not to do it, I should forget myself:
If I find him false
To such a friend, be sure he forfeits me;
In which to be more punctually resolved,
I have a project how to sift his soul,
How it is inclined; whether to yonder place,
The clear bright Palace, or black Dungeon: See,
They are onward on the way, and he returned.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: I now attend your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
You are grown perfect man, and now you float
Like to a well built Vessel; Between two Currents,
Virtue and Vice; Take this, you steer to harbour;
Take that, to eminent shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Pray your meaning.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
What fathers cares are, you shall never know,
Till you yourself have children, Now my study,
Is how to make you such, that you in them
May have a feeling of my love to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Pray Sir expound yourself; for I protest
Of all the Languages I yet have learned,
This is to me most foreign.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Then I shall;
I have lived to see you in your prime of youth
And height of Fortune, so you will but take
Occasion by the forehead; to be brief,
And cut off all superfluous circumstance,
All the ambition that I aim at now,
Is but to see you married.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Married Sir.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.p:
And to that purpose, I have found out one,
Whose Youth and Beauty may not only please
A curious eye; But her immediate means,
Able to strengthen a state competent,
Or raise a ruined Fortune.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Old Ger.
Y. Ger.
sp.p:
That I hope:
My duty and obedience still unblamed,
Did never merit such austerity;
And from a father never yet displeased.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Nay, then to come more near unto the point
Either you must resolve for present marriage,
Or forfeit all your interest in my love.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Un-say that language, I entreat you Sir.
And do not so oppress me; Or if needs
Your heavy imposition stand in force,
Resolve me by your counsel; With more safety
May I infringe a sacred vow to heaven,
Or to oppose me to your strict command?
Since one of these I must.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Now Dalauill,
I find thy words too true.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: For marry, Sir, I neither may, nor can.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Yet whore you may;
And that is no breach of any vow to Heaven:
Pollute the Nuptial bed with Mechal sin;
Aspires the honour of a noble friend;
Forfeit thy reputation, here below.
And the interest that thy Soul might claim above,
In yon blessed City: These you may, and can,
With untouched conscience: O, that I should live
to see the hopes that I have stored so long,
Thus in a moment ruined: And the staff,
On which my old decrepit age should lean;
Before my face thus broken: On which trusting,
I thus abortively, before my time,
Fall headlong to my Grave.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Old Ger.
sp.p:
Never, never son:
For till thou canst acquit thyself of scandal,
And me of my suspicion; Here, even here,
Where I have measured out my length of earth;
I shall expire my last.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Both these I can:
Then rise Sir, I entreat you; And that innocency,
Which poisoned by the breath of Calumny, cast you thus low,
Shall, these few stains wiped off, with better thoughts erect you.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Well, Say on.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
There is but one fire from which this smoke may grow;
Namely, the unmatched yoke of youth; And
In which, If ever I occasion was,
Of the smallest breach; The greatest implacable mischief
Adultery can threaten, fall on me;
Of you may I be disavowed a son;
And unto Heaven a servant: For that Lady,
As she is Beauties mirror, so I hold her
For Chastities examples: From her tongue,
Never came language, that arrived my ear,
That even censorious Cato, lived he now,
Could misinterpret; Never from her lips,
Came unchaste kiss; Or from her constant eye,
Look savouring of the least immodesty: Further -

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Enough; One only thing remains, which on thy part performed,
Assures firm credit to these thy protestations.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Name it then.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Take hence the occasion of this common fame;
Which hath already spread itself so far,
To her dishonour and thy prejudice, From this day forward,
To forbear the house: This do upon my blessing.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: As I hope it, I will not fail your charge.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.p: I am satisfied.

div2.stage: Enter at one doore an Vsurer and his Man, at the other, Old Lionell with his seruant: In the midst Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
To which hand shall I turn me; Here is my Master
Hath been to enquire of him that sold the house,
Touching the murder; Here is an Usuring Rascal,
Of whom we have borrowed money to supply
Our prodigal expenses; Broke our day,
And owe him still the Principal and Use:
Were I to meet them single, I have brain
To oppose both, and to come off unscarred;
But if they do assault me, and at once.
Not Hercules himself could stand that odds:
Therefore I must encounter them by turns;
And to my Master first: O Sir, well met.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
What Reignald; I but now met with the man,
Of whom I bought yon house.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
What, did you Sir?
But did you speak of aught concerning that
Which I last told you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Yes, I told him all.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Then am I cast: But I pray tell me Sir,
Did he confess the murder?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: No such thing; Most stiffly he denies it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Impudent wretch; Then serve him with a warrant, let the Officer
Bring him before a Justice, you shall hear
What I can say against him; Sfoot deny it:
But I pray Sir excuse me, yonder is one
With whom I have some business; Stay you here,
And but determine what is best course to take,
And note how I will follow it.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Be brief then.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Now, If I can as well put off my Use-man,
This day, I shall be master of the field.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p: That should be Lionells man.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The same, I know him.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
After so many frivolous delays,
There is now some hope. He that was wont to shun us,
And to absent himself, accosts us freely;
And with a pleasant countenance: Well met Reignald,
What is this money ready?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Never could you
Have come in better time.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
Where is your master, young Lionell, it something troubles me,
That he should break his day.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: A word in private,

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
Tush, Private me no privates, in a word,
Speak, are my moneys ready?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Not so loud.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
I will be louder yet; Give me my moneys,
Come, tender me my moneys.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
We know you have a throat, wide as your conscience;
You need not use it now - Come, get you home.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p: Home?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Yes, home I say, return by three a Clock.
And I will see all cancelled.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
It is now past two, and I can stay till three,
I will make that now my business, otherways.
With these loud clamours, I will haunt thee still;
Give me my Use, give me my Principal.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
This bur will still cleave to me; what, no means
To shake him off; I never was caught till now:
Come come, ye are troublesome.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
Reig.
sp.p: So so so.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
I have been still put off, from time to time,
And day to day; these are but cheating tricks,
And this is the last minute I will forbear
Thee, or thy Master: Once again, I say,
Give me my Use, give me my Principal.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Pox a this use, that hath undone so many:
And now will confound me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Hast thou heard this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and to my grief.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Come hither Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Here Sir; Nay, now I am gone.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
What use is this?
What Principal he talks of? in which language
He names my Son; And thus upbraideth thee,
What is it you owe this man?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
A trifle Sir,
Pray stop his mouth; And pay it him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I pay, what?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: If I say pay it him; Pay it him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: What is the Sum?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
A toy, the main about five hundred pounds;
And the use fifty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Call you that a toy?
To what use was it borrowed? At my departure,
I left my Son sufficient in his charge,
With surplus, to defray a large expense,
Without this need of borrowing.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
It is confessed,
Yet stop his clamorous mouth; And only say,
That you will pay it tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I pass my word.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Sir, if I bid you do it, Nay, no more words,
But say you will pay it tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: lest indeed, but tell me how these moneys were bestowed?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Safe Sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
The Sum still safe,
Why do you not then tender it yourselves?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Your ear sir; This sum joined to the rest,
Your Son hath purchased Land and Houses.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Land, dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: A goodly House, and Gardens.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Now joy on him,
That whilst his Father Merchandised abroad,
Had care to add to his estate at home:
But Reignald, wherefore Houses?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Now Lord Sir,
How dull you are; This house possessed with spirits,
And there no longer stay; Would you have had
Him, us, and all your other family,
To live, and lie in the streets; It had not Sir,
Been for your reputation.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Blessing on him,
That he is grown so thrifty.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p:
It is struck three,
My money is not yet tendered.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Pox upon him,
See him discharged, I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Vsu.
sp.p: It is enough, I have a true man's word.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Reig.
sp.p:
Never in all my time, so much to seek;
I know not what to answer.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Wherefore studiest thou?
Use men to purchase Lands at a dear rate,
And know not where they lie?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p: Call thyself to mind.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Non-plussed or never now; Where art thou brain?
O Sir, where was my memory; It is this house
That next adjoins to yours,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: My Neighbour Ricots.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p:
As I live,
I much commend your choice.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
To attach him of suspected murder; I will see it served;
Did he deny it? And in the interim, I
Will give them notice, you are now arrived,
And long to see your purchase.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Counselled well; And meet some half hour hence.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
This plunge well past,
All things fall even, to Crown my Brain at last.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Where shall we dine today?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
At the Ordinary.
I see Sir, you are but a stranger here;
This Barnet, is a place of great resort;
And commonly upon the Market days,
Here all the Country Gentlemen Appoint,
A friendly meeting; Some about affairs
Of Consequence and Profit; Bargain, Sale,
And to confer with Chap-men, some for pleasure,
To match their Horses; Wager in their Dogs,
Or try their Hawks; Some to no other end,
But only meet good Company, discourse,
Dine, drink, and spend their Money.

div2.stage: Enter Old Geraldine and Yong Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: That is the Market, We have to make this day.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
It is a Commodity, that will be easily vented:
What my worthy Friend,
You are happily encountered; O you are grown strange,
To one that much respects you; Troth the House
Hath all this time seemed naked without you;
The good Old Man doth never sit to meat,
But next his giving Thanks, he speaks of you;
There is scarce a bit, that he at Table tastes,
That can digest without a Geraldine,
You are in his mouth so frequent: He and She
Both wondering, what distaste from one, or either,
So suddenly, should alienate a Guest,
To them, so dearly welcome.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Master Dalauill,
Thus much let me for him Apologise;
Divers designs have thronged upon us late,
My weakness was not able to support
Without his help; He hath been much abroad,
At London, or else where; Besides it is Term;
And Lawyers must be followed, seldom at home,
And scarcely then at leisure.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
I am satisfied,
And I would they were so too, but I hope Sir,
In this restraint, you have not used my name.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Not, as I live.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
You are Noble - Who had thought
Tohave met with such good Company; You are it seem
But new alighted; Father and Son, ere part,
I vow we will drink a cup of Sack together:
Physicians say, It doth prepare the appetite
And stomach against dinner.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
We old men,
Are apt to take these courtesies.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: What say you Friend?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I will but enquire for one, at the next Inn,
And instantly return.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: It is enough.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Besse: How dost thou Girl?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Faith we may do how we lift for you, you are grown so
Great a stranger: We are more beholding
To Master Dalauill, He is a constant Guest:
And howsoever to some, that shall be nameless,
His presence may be graceful; Yet to others -
I could say somewhat.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
He is a noble fellow,
And my choice friend.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Come come, he is, what he is; and that the end will prove.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
And how is all at home?
Nay, we will not part without a glass of wine,
And meet so seldom: Boy,

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Anon, anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
A Pint of Claret, quickly.
Nay, sit down: The news, the news, I pray thee;
I am sure, I have been much enquired of
Thy old Master, and thy young Mistress too.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Ever your name is in my Masters mouth, and sometimes too
In hers, when she hath nothing else to think of:
Well well, I could say somewhat.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Here is your wine Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Fill Boy: Here Besse, this glass to both their healths:
Why dost weep my wench?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Nay, nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Come, I must know.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
In troth I love you Sir,
And ever wished you well; You are a Gentleman,
Whom always I respected; Know the passages
And private whisperings, of the secret love
Betwixt you and my Mistress; I dare swear,
On your part well intended: But -

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
You bear the name of Land-lord, but another
Enjoys the rent; You dote upon the shadow,
But another he bears away the substance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Be more plain.

sp.speaker: Bess.
Y. Ger.
sp.p:
You are too blame,
And Besse, you make me angry; He is my friend,
And she my second self; In all their meetings,
I never saw so much as cast of eye
Once entertained betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: That is their cunning.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
For her; I have been with her at all hours,
Both late and early; In her bed-chamber.
And often singly ushered her abroad:
Now, would she have been any man's alive,
She had been mine; You wrong a worthy Friend,
And a chaste Mistress, you are not a good Girl;
Drink that speak better of her, I could chide you,
But I will forbear; What you have rashly spoke,
Shall ever here be buried.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I am sorry my freeness should offend you,
But yet know, I am her Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Play now the Market-maid,
And prithee bout thy business.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, I shall - that man should be so fooled.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
She a Prostitute?
Nay, and to him my troth plight, and my Friend;
As possible it is, that Heaven and Earth
Should be in love together, meet and kiss,
And so cut off all distance: What strange frenzy
Came in this wenches brain, so to surmise?
Were she so base? his nobleness is such,
He would not entertain it for my sake:
Or he so bent? His hot and lust burnt appetite
Would be soon quenched, at the mere contemplation
Of her most Pious and Religious life.
The Girl was much to blame; Perhaps her Mistress
Hath stirred her anger, by some word or blow,
Which she would thus revenge; Not apprehending
At what a high price Honour is to be rated;
Or else someone that envies her rare virtue,
Might hire her thus to brand it; Or, who knows
But the young wench may fix a thought on me;
And to divert me from her Mistress love,
May raise this false aspersion? howsoever,
My thoughts on these two columns fixed are,
She is good as fresh, and purely chaste as fair.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O Sir, you are the Needle, and if the whole County of Middlesex
had been turned to a mere Bottle of Hay, I had been enjoined to
have found you out, or never more returned back to my old Master:
There is a Letter Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Clo.
sp.p:
I shall Sir: This is Market-day, and here acquaintance commonly
meet; and whom have I encountered? my gossip Pint-pot,
and brim full; nay, I mean to drink with you before I part, and how
doth all your worshipful kindred? your sister Quart, your pater-Pottle, (who was ever a Gentleman's fellow) and your old grandsire
Gallon; they cannot choose but be all in health, since so many healths
have been drunk out of them: I could wish them all here, and in
no worse state than I see you are in at this present; howsoever gossip,
since I have met you hand to hand, I will make bold to drink to
you - Nay, either you must pledge me, or get one to do it for you;
Do you open your mouth towards me? well, I know what you would
say; Here Roger, to your Master and Mistress, and all our good
friends at home; gramercy gossip, if I should not pledge thee, I were
worthy to be turned out to Grass, and stand no more at Livery: And
now in requital of this courtesy I will begin one health to you and all
your society in the Cellar, to Peter Pipe, Harry Hogshead, Bartholomew
Butt, and little master Randall Rundlet, to Timothy Taster, and
all your other great and small friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
He writes me here,
That at my discontinuance he is much grieved,
Desiring me, as I have ever tendered
Or him or his, to give him satisfaction
Touching my discontent; and that in person,
By any private meeting.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Aye Sir, it is very true; The Letter speaks no more
Than he wished me to tell you by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Thou art then of his counsel?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: His Privy if it please you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Though never so strict hath been my fathers charge,
A little I will dispense with it, for his love;
Commend me to thy Master, tell him from me,
On Monday night (then will my leisure serve)
I will by Heaven's assistance visit him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
On Monday Sir:
That is as I remember, just the day before Tuesday.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
But it will be midnight first, at which late hour,
Please him to let the Garden door stand ope,
At that I will enter; But conditionally,
That neither Wife, Friend, Servant, no third soul
Save him, and thee to whom he trusts this message,
Know of my coming in, or passing out:
When, tell him, I will fully satisfy him
Concerning my forced absence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am something oblivious; Your message would be the truelier
delivered if it were set down in black and white.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I will call for Pen and Ink,
And instantly dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Now impudence, but steel my face this once,
Although I never blush after; Here is the house,
Ho, who is within? What, no man to defend
