These innocent gates from knocking?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Who is without there?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Ric.
sp.p:
Gramercy Reignald,
I love all those that wish it: You are the men
Lead merry lives, Feast, Revel, and Carouse;
You feel no tedious hours; Time plays with you,
This is your golden age.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
It was, but now Sir,
That Gold is turned to worse than Alchemy,
It will not stand the test; Those days are past,
And now our nights come on.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Tell me Reignald, is he returned from Sea?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Yes, to our grief already, but we fear
Hereafter, it may prove to all our costs.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Suspects thy Master anything?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Not yet Sir;
Now my request is, that your worship being
So near a Neighbour, therefore most disturbed,
Would not be first to peach us.

sp.speaker: Ric.
Reig.
sp.p:
Worshipful Sir;
I shall be still your Beads-man; Now the business
That I was sent about, the Old Man my Master
Claiming some interest in acquaintance past,
Desires (might it be no way troublesome)
to take free view of all your House within.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
View of my House? Why it is not set to Sale,
Nor bill upon the door; Look well upon it:
View of my House?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Ric.
sp.p:
What fancies
Should at this age possess him; Knowing the cost,
That he should dream of Building.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
It is supposed,
He hath late found a Wife out for his Son;
Now Sir, to have him near him, and that nearness
Too, without trouble, though beneath one roof,
Yet parted in two Families, He would build
And make what is picked, a perfect quadrangle,
Proportioned just with yours, were you so pleased,
to make it his example.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
Willingly; I will but order some few things within,
And then attend his coming.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Most kind coxcomb,
Great Alexander, and Agathocles,
Cæsar, and others, have been Famed, they say,
And magnified for high Facinorous deeds;
Why claim not I, an equal place with them?
Or rather a precedent: These commanded
Their Subjects, and their servants; I my Master,
And every way his equals, where I please,
Lead by the nose along; They placed their burdens
On Horses, Mules, and Camels; I, old Men
Of strength and wit, load with my knavery,
Till both their backs and brains ache; Yet poor animals,
They never complain of weight; O are you come Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I made what haste I could.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: And brought the warrant?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: See here, I have it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
It is well done, but speak, runs it
Both without Bail and Mainprize?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Nay, it carries both form and power.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Then I shall warrant him;
I have been yonder Sir,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: And what says he?

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p: Was that all?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
He spake to me, that I would speak to you,
to speak unto your son; And then again,
to speak to him, that he would speak to you;
You would release his Bargain.

div2.stage: Enter Ricot againe walking before the gate.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p:
By no means,
Men must advise before they part with Land,
Not after to repent it; It is most just,
That such as hazard, and disburse their Stocks,
Should take all gains and profits that accrue,
As well in Sale of Houses, as in Barter,
And Traffic of all other Merchandise.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
See, in acknowledgement of a Tenants duty,
He attends you at the gate; Salute him Sir.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p: My worthy Friend.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
Now as I live, all my best thoughts and wishes
Impart with yours, in your so safe return;
Your servant tells me, you have great desire
to take survey of this my house within.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p: Be it Sir, no trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
None, enter boldly;
With as much freedom, as it were your own.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: As it were mine; Why Reignald, is it not?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Lord Sir, that in extremity of grief,
You will add unto vexation; See you not
How sad he is on the sudden,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I observe it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
to part with that which he hath kept so long;
Especially his Inheritance: Now as you love
Goodness, and Honesty, torment him not
With the least word of Purchase.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Counselled well;
Thou teachest me Humanity.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
Will you enter?
Or shall I call a servant, to conduct you
Through every Room and Chamber?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
By no means;
I fear we are too much troublesome of ourselves.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: See what a goodly Gate?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: It likes me well.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p: They are well Carved.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
And cost me a good price Sir; Take your pleasure.
I have business in the Town.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Poor man, I pity him;
He hath not the heart to stay and see you come,
As it were, to take Possession; Look that Sir,
What goodly fair Bay windows?

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p: Wondrous stately.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
And what a Gallery, How costly ceiled;
What painting round about?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Every fresh object to good, adds bitterness.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Terraced above, and how below supported; do they please you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
All things beyond opinion; Trust me Reignald,
I will not forgo the Bargain, for more gain
Than half the price it cost me.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
If you would? I should not suffer you; Was not the
Money due to the Usurer, took upon good ground,
That proved well built upon? We were no fools
That knew not what we did.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: It shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Please you trust me with it, I will see it discharged.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
He hath my promise, and I will do it myself:
Never could Son have better pleased a Father,
Than in this Purchase: Hie thee instantly
Unto my house in the Country, give him notice
Of my arrive, and bid him with all speed
Post hither.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Ere I see the warrant served?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
It shall be thy first business; For my Soul
Is not at peace, till face to face, I approve
His Husbandry, and much commend his Thrift;
Nay, without pause, be gone.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
But a short journey;
For he is not far, that I am sent to seek:
I have got the start, the best part of the Race
is run already, what remains, is small,
And tire now, I should but forfeit all.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Make haste, I do entreat thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
This is the Garden gate; And here am I set to stand Sentinel,
and to attend the coming of Young Master Geraldine: Master Dalauill is
gone to his Chamber; My Mistress to hers; It is now about
Mid-night; A Banquet prepared, bottles of Wine in readiness, all the
whole Household at their rest; And no creature by this, honestly stirring,
saving I and my Old Master; He in a bye Chamber, prepared of
purpose for their private Meeting; And I here to play the Watchman,
against my will; Chauelah, Stand; Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: The Word?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Honest Roger.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
That is the Word indeed; You have leave to pass freely
Without calling my Corporal.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: How go the affairs within?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
According to promise, the business is composed, and the servants
disposed, my young Mistress reposed, my old Master according as
you proposed, attends you if you be exposed to give him meeting;
Nothing in the way being interposed, to transpose you to the least
danger: And this I dare be deposed, if you will not take my word, as
I am honest Roger.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, by your leave, I that was late but a plain Sentinel,
Will now be your Captain conductor: Follow me.

div2.stage: Table and Stooles set out; Lights: a Banquet, Wine.

sp.speaker: Winc.
Clo.
sp.p:
Till the mouths of the bottles yawn directly upon the
floor, and the bottoms turn their rails up to the feeling; Whilst
there is any blood in their bellies, I will not leave them.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: I first salute you thus.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
It could not come
From one whom I more honour; Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, since my Master begun it, I will see it go round
To all three.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Now give us leave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Talk you by yourselves, whilst I find something to say to
this: I have a tale to tell him shall make his stony heart relent.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Winc.
sp.p: Both are granted.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Then I proceed; With due acknowledgement
Of all your more than many courtesies:
You have been my second father, and your wife,
My noble and chaste Mistress; All your servants
At my command; And this your bounteous Table,
As free and common as my Fathers house;
Neither against any, or the least of these,
Can I commence just quarrel.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
What might then be
The cause of this constraint, in thus absenting
Yourself from such as love you?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Winc.
sp.p: How can these, in any way be questioned?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
O dear Sir,
Bad tongues have been too busy with us all;
Of which I never yet had time to think,
But with sad thoughts and griefs unspeakable:
It hath been whispered by some wicked ones,
But loudly thundered in my fathers ears,
By some that have maligned our happiness;
(Heaven, if it can brooke slander, pardon them)
That this my customary coming hither,
Hath been to base and sordid purposes:
To wrong your bed; Injure her chastity;
And be mine own undoer: Which, how false?

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: As Heaven is true, know it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Now this Calumny
Arriving first unto my fathers ears,
His easy nature was induced to think,
That these things might perhaps be possible:
I answered him, as I would do to Heaven:
And cleared myself in his suspicious thoughts,
As truly, as the high all-knowing Judge
Shall of these stains acquit me; which are merely
Aspersions and untruths: The good old man
Possessed with my sincerity, and yet careful
Of your renown, her honour, and my fame;
To stop the worst that scandal could inflict;
And to prevent false rumours, charges me,
The cause removed, to take away the effect;
Which only could be, to forbear your house;
And this upon his blessing: You hear all.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
And I of all acquit you: This your absence,
With which my love most cavilled; Orators
In your behalf. Had such things past betwixt you,
Not threats nor chidings could have driven you hence:
It pleads in your behalf, and speaks in hers;
And arms me with a double confidence,
Both of your friendship, and her loyalty:
I am happy in you both, and only doubtful
Which of you two doth most impart my love:
You shall not hence tonight.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Pray pardon Sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: You are in your lodging.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: But my fathers charge.

sp.speaker: Winc.
Y. Ger.
sp.p: You are powerful.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
This night, of purpose, I have parted beds,
Faining myself not well, to give you meeting;
Nor can be aught suspected by my Wife,
I have kept all so private: Now it is late,
I will steal up to my rest; But howsoever,
Let us not be strange in our writing, that way daily
We may confer without the least suspect,
In spite of all such base calumnious tongues;
So, Now good-night sweet friend

div2.stage: He goes in at one doore, and comes out at another.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
May he that made you
So just and good, still guard you. Not to bed,
So I perhaps might over-sleep myself,
And then my tardy waking might betray me
To the more early household; Thus as I am,
I will rest me on this Pallet; But in vain,
I find no sleep can fasten on mine eyes,
There are in this disturbed brain of mine
So many mutinous fancies: This, to me,
Will be a tedious night; How shall I spend it?
No Book that I can spy? no company?
A little let me recollect myself;
O, what more wished company can I find,
Suiting the apt occasion, time and place;
Than the sweet contemplation of her Beauty;
And the fruition too, time may produce,
Of what is yet lent out? It is a sweet Lady,
And every way accomplished: Hath mere accident
Brought me thus near, and I not visit her?
Should it arrive her ear, perhaps might breed
Our lasting separation; For betwixt Lovers,
No quarrel is to unkindness, Sweet opportunity
Offers prevention, and invites me to it:
The house is known to me, the stairs and rooms;
The way unto her chamber frequently
Trodden by me at mid-night, and all hours:
How joyful to her would a meeting be,
So strange and unexpected; Shadowed too
Beneath the veil of night; I am resolved
To give her visitation, in that place
Where we have past deep vows, her bed-chamber:
My fiery love this darkness makes seem bright,
And and this the path that leads to my delight.
And this the gate unto it; I will; listen first,
Before too rudely I disturb her rest:
And gentle breathing; Ha? she is sure awake,
For in the bed two whisper, and their voices
Appear to me unequal; - One a woman's -
And hers; - The other should be no maids tongue,
It bears too big a tone; And hark, they laugh;
(Damnation) But list further; The other sounds -
Like - It is the same false perjured traitor, Dalauill,
To friend and goodness: Unchaste impious woman,
False to all faith, and true conjugal love;
There is met, a Serpent and a Crocodile;
A Synon and a Circe: O, to what
May I compare you? - But my Sword,
I will act a noble execution,
On two unmatched for sordid villainy: -
I left it in my Chamber, And thanks Heaven
That I did so; It hath prevented me
From playing a base Hang-man; Sin securely,
Whilst I, although for many, yet less faults,
Strive hourly to repent me; I once loved her,
And was to him entired; Although I pardon,
Heaven will find time to punish, I will not stretch
My just revenge so far, as once by blabbing,
To make your brazen Impudence to blush;
Damn on, revenge too great; And to suppress
Your Souls yet lower, without hope to rise,
Heap Ossa upon Pelion; You have made me
To hate my very Country, because here bred:
Near two such monsters; First I will leave this House,
And then my Fathers; Next I will take my leave,
Both of this Clime and Nation, Travel till
Age snow upon this Head: My passions now,
Are unexpressible, I will end them thus;
Ill man, bad Woman, your unheard of treachery,
This unjust censure, on a Just man give,
To seek out place, where no two such can live.

div2.stage: Enter Dalauill in a Night-gowne: Wife in a Night-tyre, as comming from Bed.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
A happy Morning now betide you Lady,
To equal the content of a sweet Night.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
It hath been to my wish, and your desire;
And this your coming by presented love
Unto my Sister Prudentella cuts oft suspicion
Of any such converse betwixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: It hath been wisely carried.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: One thing troubles me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: What is that my Dearest?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Why your Friend Geraldine,
Should on the sudden thus absent himself?
Has he had think you no intelligence,
Of these our private meetings.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
No, on my Soul,
For therein hath my brain exceeded yours;
I studying to engross you to myself,
Of his continued absence have been cause;
Yet he of your affection no way jealous,
Or of my Friendship - How the plot was cast,
You at our better leisure shall partake,
The air grows cold, have care unto your health,
Suspicious eyes are over us, that yet sleep,
But with the dawn, will open; Sweet retire you
To your warm Sheets; I now to fill my own,
That have this Night been empty.

sp.speaker: Wife.
Dal.
sp.p:
Doubt it not I pray,
Whilst Day frights Night, and Night pursues the day:
Good morrow.

div2.stage: Enter Reignald, Y. Lionell, Blanda, Scapha, Rioter, and two Gallants, Reig. with a Key in his hand.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Now is the Goal delivery; Through this back gate
Shift for yourselves, I here unprison all.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
But tell me, how shall we dispose ourselves?
We are as far to seek now, as at the first;
What is it to reprieve us for few hours,
And now to suffer, better had it been
At first, to have stood the trial, so by this,
We might have past our Penance.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Sweet Reignald.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Honest rogue.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: If now thou failest us, then we are lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
This same sweet Reignald, and this honest rogue,
Hath been the Burgess, under whose protection
You all this while have lived, free from Arrests,
But now, the Sessions of my power is broke up,
And you exposed to Actions, Warrants, Writs,
For all the hellish rabble are broke loose,
Of Sergeants, Sheriffs, and Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Guard us Heaven.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I tell you as it is; Nay, I myself
That have been your Protector, now as subject
To every varlets Pestle, for you know
How I am engaged with you - At whose suit sir.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Why didst thou Start.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I was afraid some Catchpole stood behind me,
To clap me on the Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p:
No such thing; Yet I protest
Thy fear did fright us all.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: I knew your guilty consciences.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: No Brain left?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: No crotchet for my sake?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
One kiss then Sweet,
Thus shall my crotchets, and your kisses meet.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Nay, tell us what to trust to.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Lodge yourselves
In the next Tavern, there is the Cash that is left,
Go, health it freely for my good success;
Nay, Drown it all, let not a Tester scape
To be consumed in rot-gut; I have begun,
And I will stand the period.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: Bravely spoke.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Or perish in the conflict.

sp.speaker: Rio.
sp.p: Worthy Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Y. Lio.
sp.p: And die in it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Well hast thou spoke my noble Charlemaine,
With these thy Peers about thee.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
May good Speed
Attend thee still.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: The end still crowns the deed.

div2.stage: Enter Old Lionell, and the first Owner of the House.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p:
Sir sir, your threats nor warrants, can fright me:
My honesty and innocency is known
Always to have been unblemished; Would you could
As well approve your own Integrity,
As I shall doubtless acquit myself
Of this surmised murder.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Rather Surrender
The price I paid, and take into thy hands
This haunted mansion, or I will prosecute
My wrongs, even to the utmost of the Law,
Which is no less than death.

sp.speaker: Own.
Clo.
sp.p:
This is the House, but where is the noise that was wont to be
in it? I am sent hither, to deliver a Note, to two young Gentlemen
that here keep Revel-rout; I remember it, since the last Massacre of
Meat that was made init; But it seems, that the great Storm that
was raised then, is ceased now; I have other Notes to deliver, one to
Master Rycott - and - I shall think on them all in order; My
Old Master makes a great Feast, for the parting of young Master Geraldine,
who is presently upon his departure for Travel, and the better
to grace it, hath invited many of his Neighbours and Friends; Where
will be Old Master Geraldine - his Son, and I cannot tell how
many; But this is strange, the Gates shut up at this time a day, belike
they are all Drunk and laid to sleep, if they be, I will wake them, with
a Murrain.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
What desperate fellow is this, that ignorant
Of his own danger, thunders at these Gates?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ho, Reignald, Riotous Reignald, Revelling Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p:
What madness doth possess thee, honest Friend,
To touch that Hammers handle?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
What madness doth possess thee, honest Friend,
To ask me such a question?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Nay, stir not you?

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p: Not I; The game begins.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: How dost thou, art thou well?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes very well, I thank you, how do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: No alteration; What change about thee?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Not so much change about me at this time,
As to change you a Shilling into two Testers.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Yet I advise thee Fellow, for thy good,
Stand further from the Gate.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And I advise thee Friend, for thine own good, stand not betwixt
me and the Gate, but give me leave to deliver my errant; Ho,
Reignald, you mad Rascal.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
In vain thou thunderest at these silent Doors,
Where no man dwells to answer, saving Ghosts,
Furies, and Sprites.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Ghosts; Indeed there has been much walking, in and about the
House after Mid-night.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Strange noise oft heard.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Yes, terrible noise, that none of the neighbours could take any
rest for it, I have heard it myself.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: You hear this; Here is more witness.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p: Very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Which you shall dearly answer - whooping.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And hollowing.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: And shouting.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And crying out, till the whole house rung again.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Which thou hast heard?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oftener than I have toes and fingers.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Thou wilt be deposed of this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I will be sworn to it, and that is as good.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Very good still; Yet you are innocent:
Shall I entreat thee friend, to avouch as much
Here by, to the next Justice.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I will take my soldier's oath on it.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: A soldier's oath, What is that?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
My corporal oath; And you know Sir, a Corporal is an office
belonging to a soldier.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Yet you are clear?
Murder will come to light.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p: So will your gullery too.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
They say my old Master is come home; I will see if he will
turn me out of doors, as the young man has done: I have laid rods
in piss for somebody, scape Reignald as he can, and with more freedom
than I dust late, I boldly now dare knock.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
More mad-men yet; I think since my last voyage,
Half of the world is turned frantic: What dost mean,
Or longest thou to be blasted?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
O Sir, you are welcome home; It was time to come
Ere all was gone to havoc.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
My old servant? before I shall demand of further business,
Resolve me why thou thunderest at these doors,
Where thou knowest none inhabits?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Are they gone Sir?
It was well yet they have left the house behind;
For all the furniture, to a bare bench,
I am sure is spent and wasted.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Where is my son,
That Reignald posting for him with such speed,
Brings him not from the Country?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Country Sir?
It is a thing they know not; Here they Feast,
Dice, Drink, and Drab; The company they keep,
Cheaters and Roaring Lads, and these attended
By Bawds and Queans: Your son hath got a Strumpet,
On whom he spends all that your sparing left,
And here they keep court; To whose damned abuses,
Reignald gives all encouragement.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Rob.
sp.p:
Last week I am sure, so late, and the other day,
Such Revels were here kept.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: And by my son?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, and his servant Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: And this house at all not haunted?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Save Sir with such Sprites.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p: This Murder will come out.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But see, in happy time here comes my
Neighbour of whom he bought this mansion; He I am sure
More amply can resolve me: I pray Sir,
What sums of moneys have you late received
Of my young son?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Of him? None I assure you.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: What of my servant Reignald?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
But devise
What to call less than nothing, and that sum
I will confess received.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Ric.
sp.p:
You may do well to pay it then, for here is witness
Sufficient of your words.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p:
I speak no more than what I purpose; Just so much I owe you,
And ere I sleep will tender.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
I shall be as ready to receive it, and as willing,
As you can be to pay it.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But provided,
You will confess seven hundred pounds received
Before hand of my son?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
But by your favour;
Why should I yield seven hundred received
Of them I never dealt with? Why? For what?
What reason? What condition? Where or when
Should such a sum be paid me?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Why? For this bargain: And for what? This house:
Reason? Because you sold it: The conditions? Such
As were agreed between you: Where and When?
That only hath escaped me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Madness all.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Was I not brought to take free view thereof,
As of mine own possession?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
I confess;
Your servant told me you had found out a wife
Fit for your son, and that you meant to build;
Desired to take a friendly view of mine,
To make it your example: But for selling,
I tell you Sir, my wants be not so great,
To change my house to Coin.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Spare Sir your anger,
And turn it into pity; Neighbours and friends,
I am quite lost, was never man so fooled,
And by a wicked servant; Shame and blushing
Will not permit to tell the manner how,
Lest I be made ridiculous to all:
My fears are to inherit what is yet left;
He hath made my son away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: That is my fear too.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Friends, as you would commiserate a man
Deprived at once, both of his wealth and son;
And in his age, by one I ever tendered
More like a son than servant: By imagining
My case were yours, have feeling of my griefs
And help to apprehend him;
Furnish me with Cords and Fetters,
I will lay him safe in Prison within Prison.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: We will assist you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And all;
But not to do the least hurt to my old friend Reignald.

div2.stage: Enter Reignald with a Horne in his pocket: they withdraw behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
His Legs will be as nimble as his Brain,
And it will be difficult to seize the slave,
Yet your endeavours, pray peace, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
My heart miss-gives, for it is not possible
But that in all these windings and indents
I shall be found at last: I will take that course
That men both troubled and affrighted do,
Heap doubt on doubt, and as combustions rise,
Try if from many I can make my peace,
And work mine own atonement.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Stand you close,
Be not yet seen, but at your best advantage
Hand him, and bind him fast: Whilst I dissemble
As if I yet knew nothing.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I suspect
And find there is trouble in my Masters looks;
Therefore I must not trust myself too far
Within his fingers.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Reignald?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Worshipful Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: What says my son in the Country?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
That tomorrow,
Early in the morning, he will attend your pleasure,
And do as all such duteous children ought;
Demand your blessing Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Well, it is well.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: I do not like his countenance.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But Reignald? I suspect the honesty
And the good meaning of my neighbour here,
Old master Ricott; Meeting him but now,
And having some discourse about the house,
He makes all strange, and tells me in plain terms,
He knows of no such matter.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Tell me that Sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
I tell thee as it is:
Nor that such moneys, took up at use, were ever tendered him
On any such conditions.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
I cannot blame your worship to be pleasant,
Knowing at what an under-rate we bought it, but you ever
Were a most merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p:
(Impudent slave)
But Reignald, he not only doth deny it,
But offers to depose Himself and Servants,
No such thing ever was.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Now Heaven, to see to what this world is grown to.
I will make him -

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Nay more, this man will not confess the Murder.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Which both shall dearly answer; You have warrant
For him already; But for the other Sir,
If he deny it, he had better -

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Appear Gentlemen,
It is a fit time to take him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: I discover the Ambush that is laid for me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Come nearer Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
First sir resolve me one thing, amongst other Merchandise
Bought in your absence by your Son and me,
We engrossed a great commodity of Combs,
And how many sorts think you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
You might buy
Some of the bones of Fishes, some of Beasts,
Box-combs, and Ivory-combs.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
But besides these, we have for Horses Sir,
Main-combs, and Curry-combs; Now Sir for men,
We have Head-combs, Beard-combs, Aye and Cox-combs too;
Take view of them at your pleasure, whilst for my part,
I thus bestow myself.

div2.stage: They all appeare with Cords and Shackels, Whilest hee gets vp.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well said Reignald, nobly put off Reignald,
Look to thyself Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why dost thou climb thus?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Only to practice
The nimbleness of my Arms and Legs,
Ere they prove your Cords and Fetters.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Why to that place?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Why? because Sir it is your own House; It hath been my Harbour
long, and now it must be my Sanctuary; Dispute now, and
I will answer.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p:
Villain, what devilish meaning hadst thou in it,
To challenge me of Murder?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
O sir, the man you killed is alive at this present to justify it:
I am, quoth he, a Transmarine by birth -

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
Why, challenge me receipt of Moneys, and to give abroad,
That I had sold my House?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Why? because sir,
Could I have purchased Houses at that rate,
I had meant to have bought all London.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, and Middlesex too, and I would have been thy half Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Yours are great,
My wrongs insufferable; As first, to fright me
From mine own dwelling, till they had consumed
The whole remainder of the little left;
Besides, out of my late stock got at Sea,
Discharge the clamorous Usurer; Make me accuse
This man of Murder; Be at charge of warrants;
And challenging this my worthy Neighbour of
Forswearing Sums he never yet received;
Fool me, to think my Son that had spent all,
Had by his thrift bought Land; I and him too,
To open all the secrets of his House
To me, a Stranger, O thou insolent villain,
What to all these canst answer?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Guilty, guilty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: But to my Son's death, what thou slave?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Produce him then; In the mean time, and -
Honest Friends, get Ladders.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Yes, and come down in your own Ropes.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p: I will fetch a Piece and shoot him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
So the warrant in my Masters pocket, will serve for my Murder;
And ever after shall my Ghost haunt this House.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
And I will say like Reignald,
This Ghost and I am Friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
Bring faggots, I will set fire upon the House,
Rather than this endure.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
To burn Houses is Felony, and I will not out
Till I be fired out; But since I am Besieged thus,
I will summon supplies unto my Rescue.

div2.stage: Hee windes a Horne. Enter Young Lionell, Rioter, two Gallants Blanda, &c.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
Old Lio.
Clo.
sp.p:
The one you have nothing to do withal, here is his Ticket for
his discharge; Another for you Sir, to Summon you to my Masters
Feast, For you, and you, where I charge you all to appear, upon his
displeasure, and your own apparels.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
This is my Friend, the other one I loved,
Only because they have been dear to him
That now will strive to be more dear to you;
Vouchsafe their pardon.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
All dear, to me indeed, for I have paid for it soundly,
Yet for thy sake, I am atoned with all; Only that wanton,
Her, and her Company, abandon quite;
So doing, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p: A just Condition, and willingly subscribed to.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But for that Villain; I am now devising
What shame, what punishment remarkable,
To inflict on him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
Old Lio.
sp.p: Sirrah, come down.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Not till my Pardon is sealed, I will rather stand here
Like a Statue, in the Fore-front of your house
For ever; Like the picture of Dame Fortune
Before the Fortune Play-house.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
If I have here
But any Friend amongst you, join with me
In this petition.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Good Sir, for my sake, I resolved you truly
Concerning Whooping, the Noise, the Walking, and the Sprites,
And for a need, can show you a Ticket for him too.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p:
I impute my wrongs rather to knavish Cunning,
Than least pretended Malice.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
What he did,
Was but for his Young Master, I allow it
Rather as sports of Wit, than injuries;
No other pray esteem them.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Reig.
sp.p:
I knew that, therefore this was my Invention,
For Policy is the art still of Prevention.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Come down then Reignald, first on your hands and feet, and
then on your knees to your Master; Now Gentlemen, what do you
say to your inviting to my Masters Feast.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: We will attend him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
Reig.
sp.p:
I was the Fox,
But I from henceforth, will no more the Cox -
Comb, put upon your pate.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.p: Let us walk Gentlemen

div2.stage: Enter Old Geraldine, and Young Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Son, let me tell you, you are ill advised;
And doubly to be blamed, by undertaking
Unnecessary travel; Grounding no reason
For such a rash and giddy enterprise:
What profit aim you at, you have not reaped;
What Novelty affords the Christian world,
Of which your view hath not participated
In a full measure; Can you either better
Your language or experience? Yourself-will
Hath only purpose to deprive a father
Of a loved son, and many noble friends,
Of your much wished acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
O, dear Sir,
Do not, I do entreat you, now repent you
Of your free grant; Which with such care and study,
I have so long, so often laboured for.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.p:
Say that may be dispensed with, show me reason
Why you desire to steal out of your Country,
Like some Malefactor that had forfeited
His life and freedom; Here is a worthy Gentleman
Hath for your sake invited many guests,
To his great charge, only to take of you
A parting leave; You send him word you cannot,
After, you may not come: Had not my urgence,
Almost compulsion, driven you to his house,
The unkindness might have forfeited your love,
And raced you from his will; In which he hath given you
A fair and large estate; Yet you of all this strangeness,
Show no sufficient ground.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Then understand;
The ground thereof took his first birth from you,
It was you first charged me to forbear the house,
And that upon your blessing: Let it not then
Offend you Sir, if I so great a charge
Have strived to keep so strictly.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Me perhaps,
You may appease, and with small difficulty,
Because a Father; But how satisfy
Their dear, and on your part, unmerited love?
But this your last obedience may salve all:
We now grow near the house.

div2.stage: Enter Wincott, Wife, Ricott, the two Lionells, Owner, Dalauill, Prudentilla, Reignald, Rioter.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Whose doors, to me,
Appear as horrid as the gates of Hell:
Where shall I borrow patience, or from whence?
To give a meeting to this viperous brood,
Of Friend and Mistress.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
You have entertained me with a strange discourse
Of your man's knavish wit, but I rejoice,
That in your safe return, all ends so well:
Most welcome you, and you, and indeed all;
To whom I am bound, that at so short a warning,
Thus friendly, you will deign to visit me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
It seems my absence hath begot some sport,
Thank my kind servant here.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Not so much worth Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
But though their riots tripped at my estate,
They have not quite overthrown it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
But see Gentlemen, these whom we most expected,
come at length; This I proclaim the master of the Feast,
In which to express the bounty of my love,
I will show myself no niggard.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Your choice favours,
I still taste in abundance.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Methinks it would not misbecome me Sir,
To chide your absence; That have made yourself,
To us, so long a stranger.

div2.stage: Hee turnes away sad, as not being minded.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Pardon me Sir,
Thathave not yet, since your return from Sea,
Voted the least fit opportunity,
To entertain you with a kind salute.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Most kindly Sir I thank yon.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Methinks friend,
You should expect green rushes to be strowed,
After such discontinuance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Mistress Prudentella,
I have not seen you long, but greet you thus,
May you be Lady of a better husband
Than I expect a wife.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
I like that greeting:
Nay, enter Gentlemen; Dinner perhaps
Is not yet ready, but the time we stay,
We will find some fresh discourse to spend away.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Not speak to me? nor once vouchsafe an answer,
But sleight me with a poor and base neglect?
No, nor so much as cast an eye on her,
Or least regard, though in a seeming show
She courted a reply? betwixt him and her,
Nay him and me, this was not wont to be;
If she have brain to apprehend as much
As I have done, she will quickly find it out:
Now as I live, as our affections meet,
So our conceits, and she hath singled him
To some such purpose: I will retire myself,
Not interrupt their conference.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are sad Sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: I know no cause.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Then can I show you some;
Who could be otherways, to leave a Father
So careful, and each way so provident?
To leave so many, and such worthy Friends?
To abandon your own country? These are some,
Nor do I think you can be much the merrier
For my sake?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Wife.
Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Shall my oppressed sufferance yet break forth
Into impatience, or endure her more?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
But since by no persuasion, no entreats,
Your settled obstinacy can be swayed,
Though you seem desperate of your own dear life,
Have care of mine, for it exists in you.
O Sir, should you miscarry I were lost,
Lost and forsaken; Then by our past vows,
And by this hand once given me, by these tears,
Which are but springs begetting greater floods,
I do beseech thee, my dear Geraldine,
Look to thy safety, and preserve thy health;
Have care into what company you fall;
Travel not late, and cross no dangerous Seas;
For till Heavens bless me in thy safe return,
How will this poor heart suffer?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
Wife.
sp.p: What? no answer?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Yes, thou hast spoke to me in Showers,
I will reply in Thunder; Thou Adulteress,
That hast more poison in thee than the Serpent,
Who was the first that did corrupt thy sex,
The Devil.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To whom speaks the man?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
To thee, falsest of all that ever man termed fair;
Hath Impudence so steeled thy smooth soft skin,
It cannot blush? Or sin so obdurate thy heart,
It doth not quake and tremble? Search thy conscience,
There thou shalt find a thousand clamorous tongues
To speak as loud as mine doth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Save from yours,
I hear no noise at all.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
I will play the Doctor
To open thy deaf ears; Monday the Ninth
Of the last Month; Canst thou remember that?
That Night more black in thy abhorred sin,
Than in the gloomy darkness; That the time.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Monday?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Wouldst thou the place know? Thy polluted Chamber,
So often witness of my sin-less vows;
Wouldst thou the Person? One not worthy Name,
Yet to torment thy guilty Soul the more,
I will tell him thee, That Monster Dalauill;
Wouldst thou your Bawd know? Mid-night, that the hour;
The very words thou spake? Now what would Geraldine
Say, if he saw us here? To which was answered,
Tush he is a Coxcomb, fit to be so fooled:
No blush? What, no faint Fever on thee yet?
How hath thy black sins changed thee? Thou Medusa,
Those Hairs that late appeared like golden Wires,
Now crawl with Snakes and Adders; Thou art ugly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
And yet my glass, till now, never told me so;
Who gave you this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Only he,
That pitying such an Innocency as mine,
Should by two such delinquents be betrayed,
He brought me to that place by miracle;
And made me an ear witness of all this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
But think what thou hast lost
To forfeit me; I not withstanding these,
(So fixed was my love and unutterable)
I kept this from thy Husband, nay all ears,
With thy transgressions smothering mine own wrongs,
In hope of thy Repentance.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Which begins thus low upon my knees.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Tush, bow to Heaven,
Which thou hast most offended; I alas,
Save in such (Scarce unheard of) Treachery,
Most sinful like thyself;
Wherein, O wherein, hath my unspotted and unbounded Love
deserved the least of these? Sworn to be made a stale
For term of life; And all this for my goodness;
Die, and die soon, acquit me of my Oath,
But prithee die repentant; Farewell ever,
It is thou, and only thou hast Banished me,
Both from my Friends and Country.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O, I am lost.

div2.stage: Enter Dalauill meeting Young Geraldine going out.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Why how now, what is the business?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
Go take her up, whom thou hast oft thrown Down,
Villain.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
That was no language from a Friend,
It had too harsh an accent; But how is this?
My Mistress thus low cast upon the earth
Gravelling and breathless, Mistress, Lady, Sweet -

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
O tell me if thy name be Geraldine,
Thy very looks will kill me?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
View me well,
I am no such man; See, I am Dalauill.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Thou art then a Devil, that presents before me
My horrid sins; persuades me to despair;
When he like a good Angel sent from Heaven,
Besought me of repentance; Swell sick Heart,
Even till thou burst the ribs that bound thee in;
So, there is one string cracked, flow, and flow high,
Even till thy blood distill out of mine eyes,
To witness my great sorrow.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p:
Faint again,
Some help within there, no attendant near?
Thus to expire, in this I am more wretched,
Than all the sweet fruition of her love
Before could make me happy.

div2.stage: Enter Wincott Old Geraldine, Young Geraldine, the twoLionells, Ricott, Owner, Prudentilla, Reignald, Clowne .

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
What was he clamoured so loud,
To mingle with our mirth this terror
And affright?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: See Sir, your Wife in these my arms expiring.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: My sister?

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
Support her, and by all means possible
Provide for her dear safety.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: See, she recovers.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Woman, look up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
O Sir, your pardon;
Convey me to my Chamber, I am sick,
Sick even to death, away thou Sycophant,
Out of my sight, I have besides thyself,
Too many sins about me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: My sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: The storm is coming, I must provide for harbour.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p:
What strange and sudden alteration is this,
How quickly is this clear day overcast;
But such and so uncertain are all things,
That dwell beneath the Moon.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.p:
A Woman's qualm,
Frailties that are inherent to her sex,
Soon sick, and soon recovered.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
If she misfare,
I am a man more wretched in her loss,
Than had I forfeited life and estate;
She was so good a creature.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
Ric.
sp.p:
These are casualties
That are not new, but common.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p:
Burying of Wives,
As stale as shifting shirts, or for some servants,
To flout and gull their Masters.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.p:
Best to send
And see how her fit holds her.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p:
Sir, my Sister
In these few Lines commends her last to you,
For she is now no more; What is therein writ,
Save Heaven and you, none knows, This she desired
You would take view of; and with these words expired.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
She hath made me then a free release,
Of all the debts I owed her.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
My fear is beyond pardon, Dalauill
Hath played the villain, but for Geraldine,
He hath been each way Noble - Love him still,
My peace already I have made with Heaven;
O be not you at war with me; My Honour
Is in your hands to punish, or preserve;
I am now Confessed, and only Geraldine
Hath wrought on me this unexpected good;
The Ink I write with, I wish had been my blood,
To witness my Repentance - Dalauill?
Where is he? Go seek him out.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I shall, I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
Clo.
sp.p:
He went presently to the Stable, put the Saddle upon his Horse,
put his Foot into the Stirrup, clapped his Spurs into his sides, and away
he is Galloped, as if he were to ride a Race for a Wager.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p:
All our ill lucks go with him, farewell he;
But all my best of wishes wait on you,
As my chief Friend; This meeting that was made
Only to take of you a parting leave,
Shall now be made a Marriage of our Love,
Which none save only Death shall separate.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p:
It calls me from all Travel, and from henceforth,
With my Country I am Friends.

sp.speaker: Winc.
